review.title: Towards Evidence-Based Ontology for Supporting Systematic Literature Review
review.abstract: [Background]: Systematic Literature Review (SLR) has become an important software engineering research method but costs tremendous efforts. [Aim]: This paper proposes an approach to leverage on empirically evolved ontology to support automating key SLR activities. [Method]: First, we propose an ontology, SLRONT, built on SLR experiences and best practices as a groundwork to capture common terminologies and their relationships during SLR processes; second, we present an extended version of SLRONT, the COSONT and instantiate it with the knowledge and concepts extracted from structured abstracts. Case studies illustrate the details of applying it for supporting SLR steps. [Results]: Results show that through using COSONT, we acquire the same conclusion compared with sheer manual works, but the efforts involved is significantly reduced. [Conclusions]: The approach of using ontology could effectively and efficiently support the conducting of systematic literature review.

sections.heading: B. Extending SLRONT to COSONT
sections.text: In order to demonstrate the value of ontology, we extend SLRONT to a more specific version, the COSONT. COSONT is a more detailed ontology, which aims to support cost estimates of systematic literary reviews. Since the quality of unstructured abstractions is not as good as that of structured abstractions, we make a simplification during modeling, so that unstructured abstractions can be transformed into structured ones. Therefore, five sub-classes of structured abstractions are divided into three sub-classes. sections.heading: C. Automated Query and Retrieval
sections.text: When COSONT is built, it functions as a knowledge base for further SLR studies. As key knowledge and concepts relevant to specific cost estimation issues are extracted from abstracts and inserted into the ontology structure, researchers could use SPAROL queries to retrieve them. Then, relevant analyses are performed on the retrieved results, which will save much more effort than manually reviewing each literature and extracting information from it.The next section will discuss two case studies.III. CASE STUDY Since regression and neural network are two popular estimates, we will run 2 sample scenarios to find out which approach is better.

sections.heading: A. Study 1: supporting study selection
sections.text: In this step, each student is randomly assigned about 87 of the total of 347 papers. The main criterion for inclusion / exclusion is that the work should mention both regression and neural network models; you should go through the details of the abstracts and filter out these irrelevant ones based on your personal assessment; you were also asked to log the efforts used. By way of comparison, we ask COSONT to automatically check the methodology portion of the abstracts to find relevant papers. Figure 7 gives the SPARQL query and Table I shows the result. As shown in Table 1, 11 papers are eventually identified; the manual selection is quite time-consuming; the total time is 35 person hours. With COSONT, we select the same 11 studies, but the time used by COSONT could be ignored. Note that we need time to construct COSONT, which should be added to the total time needed by the COSONT approach.
